column4: Hello!  I installed a broken package (a Brother printer driver) and now apt is broken.  It keeps saying I need to reinstall the package, but the installation from the .deb always fails.  How do I tell it to remove what it can and ignore the rest?
This is the error synaptic gives: E: The package mfc4800lpr needs to be reinstalled, but I can't find an archive for it.
E: Internal error opening cache (1). Please report.
Also, I tried purging the package with dpkg and with apt-get, as well as force-all, remove, and --ignore-missing.  Nothing helps
where did that package initially come from? it's not in the default repos
brother's printer drivers for linux website.  I was trying to install a driver for my printer.  It came in a debian package.  Would you like the URL of the site it is from?
have you tried downloading the .deb again and installing it with dpkg -i file.deb ?
and apt still complains with that error about the cache?
the .deb itself is broken.  The server's copy alway fails
a thread on the ubuntu forums suggests "sudo dpkg --remove --force-depends --force-remove-reinstreq mfc4800lpr" *might* fix the cache error
this is the error given to me by dpkg: /var/lib/dpkg/info/mfc4800lpr.postrm: line 3: /etc/init.d/lpd: No such file or directory
http://www.ubuntuforums.org/showpost.php?p=1427262&postcount=18 is for jedit, but the problem is very similar to yours
thank you so much!!! That post fixed my problems!
although it took me a while--I had installed several similar drivers, trying to get it to work
